MainHeading.RHead: Promotion to Clerical Posts by Examination
MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Promotion to Clerical Posts by Examination.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if he has received representations on the subject of an announcement of a limited examination for clerical posts in the Civil Service open to Shorthand-typists and Writing Assistants; whether having regard to the fact that prospects of promotion to the Clerical Grade were amongst the stated conditions of these officers on entering the service, it is proposed to resume promotions by the normal method; and whether the Minister has given consideration to the fact that an examination of the nature proposed is an unsuitable test for officers of long service who have been a long time away from school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Blythe) Ernest Blythe
Speaker.P: Representations on this subject have been made to me on behalf of the lower grades concerned. The test now to be applied is intended to provide the promotions which the best members of the lower grades are entitled to expect. Last year promotions were made by the ordinary means of recommendation and personal interview, but the results were not entirely satisfactory. In view of that, and owing to the large number of candidates eligible, it has been decided that, in fairness to the general body of the eligible candidates, and in order to surmount the difficulty of determining efficiently their relative merits, the test should be by means of a written examination by the Civil Service Commissioners. The Commissioners have been informed, and will, no doubt, in setting the papers take cognisance of the fact that the candidates are persons who left school seven or more years ago. I may add for the Deputy's information that it has now been decided that no entrance fee for the examination will be charged to candidates.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Finances of Agricultural Credit Corporation.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance to state how many shares were purchased by the Government in the Agricultural Credit Corporation, and how many of these shares the Government still holds; and further, if the Minister will state whether he anticipates that the Government will be called upon to pay any contribution towards the interest to shareholders, certificate holders or script holders, which interest, together with the principal, is guaranteed by the State.
The total number of shares in the Agricultural Credit Corporation, Ltd., originally purchased by the Government was 587,587, and the total number now held is 584,237.

I have received no application from the Corporation for an advance for the payment of interest on either shares or mortage bonds and I am unable to anticipate whether or not such an application will be made.
How were the shares that the Government held disposed of? Were they sold through the Stock Exchange?
They were sold in the market.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Hearing of Circuit Court Appeals.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J.T. Wolfe Mr. J.T. Wolfe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he can state the number of appeals from decisions of the Circuit Court now pending in the High Court; the date from which the services of notices of these appeals relate back and what steps he has taken or proposes to take to remove the very serious loss and inconvenience caused to litigants by the delay which has occurred and to prevent a repetition of the expense of the appointment of Special Commissioners which has previously occurred.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Fitzgerald-Kenney) James Fitzgerald-Kenney
Speaker.P: The number of appeals now pending is 301. The notices of appeals served in these cases date back to January, 1930. As regards the last part of this question, it does not appear to me possible to do anything except by legislation which I hope to introduce during this session.

MainHeading.RHead: Use of National School for Political Meetings
MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Use of National School for Political Meetings.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware that the National School of Kilglass, Co. Sligo, has been used as a meeting place for the Kilglass Branch of Cumann na nGaedheal for the past five or six years; whether he approves of the school being used for this purpose, and, if so, whether other political organisations will be afforded similar facilities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Professor O'Sullivan) John Marcus O'Sullivan
Speaker.P: I am not aware that Kilglass National School has been used as a meeting place for the Kilglass Branch of Cumann na nGaedheal. My Department is in communication with the manager of the school in the matter.
It is not proposed to relax the regulations which deal with the holding of political meetings in National Schools.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Pre-Matriculation Gaeltacht Scholarships.

Speaker.hpid: Micheál Og MacFadden Micheál Og MacFadden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he is aware that pre-Matriculation Gaeltacht Scholarships tenable in the University College, Galway, have been discontinued without sufficient notice being given to competing students, and whether he will consider the advisability of having those scholarships resumed.

Responsibility for all arrangements in connection with the award of these scholarships rests with the authorities of the University College, and I have no power to interfere in the matter. I have, however, communicated the Deputy's enquiry to the Registrar of the College, and will let him have a copy of the reply.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Bottle-making in Saorstát.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J.T. Wolfe Mr. J.T. Wolfe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he has ascertained the future prospects of the bottle-making industry in Saorstát Eireann; if the industry has now ceased to exist; and, if he will take the necessary steps to have removed the tariff which is now being paid for the protection of an industry which does not exist; if the Minister will consider the desirability of discharging or modifying the order prescribing standard bottles under the Intoxicating Liquor (General) Act, 1924, in view of the fact that it imposes a useless and entirely unnecessary burden on traders.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. McGilligan) Patrick McGilligan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. McGilligan)
Speaker.P: Efforts are being continued to secure the re-starting of this industry and the retention of the import duty is necessary to give those efforts a reasonable prospect of success.

The order prescribing standard bottles is a matter for the Minister for Justice and not for me, but in so far as I have had experience of its operation through the administration of the Weights and Measures Acts it has proved a substantial protection to the purchasing public.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - The Drumm Battery.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce to state if he still confirms the success of the Drumm Battery and to what causes he attributes the delay in the running of the experimental train between Dublin and Bray.
The claims made for the battery are being confirmed by experience and are not affected by the slow delivery of parts and equipment for the coaches in which it is to be used.
When does the Minister hope to make a definite statement as to the position of the Drumm Battery?
I cannot say when.
Can the Minister say how long he expects these delays to occur with regard to the delivery of the parts?
I did not say that there has been any delay yet.
Is the Minister not aware that the public have been expecting tests of this battery?
The public may have been misled by people who speak without authority.
Was the Minister for Justice speaking without authority when he made certain statements in Mayo on 11th August?
I cannot say until I see what he said.
Will the Minister promise to look up the “Western People” or the “Mayo News” of August 16th?
I have not time to read these papers.

MainHeading.RHead: - Refund to Users of Old Motor Cars
MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Refund to Users of Old Motor Cars.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government and Public Health whether he will state the reasons for the delay in refunding to owners of motor cars in County Sligo, the engines of which were manufactured prior to the 1st January, 1926, the portion of the Road Tax paid to which they are entitled.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government and Public Health (General Mulcahy) Richard (General) Mulcahy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Local Government and Public Health (General Mulcahy)
Speaker.P: I would refer the Deputy to my reply to Deputy's Briscoe's question on this subject on the 14th October, 1931.

Is the Minister aware that several car-owners in Co. Sligo have not received refunds of the taxes paid for the second quarter of the present year? A considerable number of persons have not received a refund of tax paid for the present half year. When does the Minister hope to be in a position to make refunds to these people?
I am aware that out of 222 claims received from Sligo, 170 have been paid.
For what period?
Some for the first quarter and some for the second and third quarters. Applications are dealt with in their order.
Some of the applications in respect of the third quarter have been paid and some in respect of the first and second quarters have not been dealt with.
Applications were probably dealt with in accordance with the date upon which they were sent.

Surely every person made an application at the time the tax was paid or immediately afterwards. There is no reason why the Department should not have paid these refunds for the first and second quarters. There may be some excuse for the half-year or for the last quarter. In one case an application was made immediately after the tax was paid in the second quarter. The Department did not even acknowledge that letter.
I will be glad to get particulars of any case like that.
I can give the Minister definite information in one case.
Is the Minister prepared to hear complaints from other owners of motor cars? I have several complaints from Cork City.

There is a very great deal of nonsense in regard to complaints made in this connection. Certain refunds are payable. They are not necessarily payable until after the end of the period involved. Upwards of 10,000 applications have been made, some for very small amounts. I have set up what I consider reasonable machinery for dealing with this matter. Nobody is inconvenienced in any very great way. In justice to the other work of the Department, I have set aside as large a staff as may reasonably be expected to deal with this work. I have already given details as to the extent to which refunds have been made in the case of Sligo. Of the number of applications received, over 75 per cent. have been paid already and I do not think that that is a very bad figure.
What is the Minister's authority for saying that claims need not necessarily be paid until the end of the quarter?
I am saying it.
What authority has the Minister for holding up claims until the end of the quarter or the half year? That is not specified in the Act or in any regulation made under the Act.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Purchase Scheme for Labourers' Cottages.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government and Public Health if he is aware of the general demand being made by cottage tenants for a purchase scheme for labourers' cottages or at least for an enquiry into the advisability of such a scheme; if he is aware that the General Council of County Councils recently passed a motion in favour of such action, and if he will consider having a committee at once appointed to inquire into all the relevant particulars and report thereon.
I would refer the Deputy to my reply to Deputy Morrissey's question on this subject on the 11th March, 1931. I have nothing to add to that reply.
In view of the attitude taken up by the General Council of County Councils will the Minister say when he will be in a position to appoint a committee?
I do not think the General Council of County Councils have had anything to add to what they said before on this subject. The matter has been fully investigated by the different Boards of Health.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Gaeltacht Housing Scheme in Raphoe.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands and Fisheries to state whether any consideration has been given to resolutions passed at a meeting of the clergy of the Raphoe Diocese, Co. Donegal, regarding the slow rate of progress of the Gaeltacht Housing Scheme in that county, and, if so, will the Minister state whether any steps have been taken to speed up the work in connection with this scheme in Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Lands and Fisheries (Mr. Lynch) Fionán Lynch
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Lands and Fisheries (Mr. Lynch)
Speaker.P: The staff of surveyors dealing with applications from County Donegal under the Housing (Gaeltacht) Act, 1929, had been strengthened in March of this year, and I am satisfied that the rate of progress in dealing with applications from that county since that date has been satisfactory.
Does the Minister seriously suggest that he is satisfied with the rate of progress?
Absolutely.
Then I must say that the Minister is easily satisfied.
Does the Deputy know anything at all about the rate of progress in Donegal?

I know very well, and the Minister himself knows very well, if only he will admit it, that the progress there is very slow, and if the Minister is at all serious about this matter he should make some effort to speed up the work.
I am quite aware of the speedy progress that is being made, but the Deputy is not.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Grazing Rights on Muckish Mountain.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands and Fisheries to state whether the question of the grazing rights on Muckish Mountain, by the tenant farmers of Gortnaleck, Kilmacloo and Creansmear, Stewart Bam Estate, Co. Speaker.NameTxt: Parliamentary Secretary to Minister for Lands and Fisheries (Mr. Roddy)

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Boland (for Mr. Corkery) Mr. G. Boland (for Mr. Corkery)
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands and Fisheries if he will state the area and valuation of the demesne lands in Saorstát Eireann now held by (a) the Marquis of Sligo, (b) Lord Barrymore, and (c) the Earl of Bandon.

In the schedules of particulars lodged by the Marquis of Sligo in respect of his estate in Co. Mayo he was described as owner of Westport demesne and adjoining untenanted lands with an area of 1,570a. 2r. 3p. and a poor law valuation, including the mansion house, of £1,203 6s. As regards the Barrymore demesne in Co. Cork, this would appear to comprise 765a. 2r. 5p. of the lands of Foaty with a poor law valuation, including buildings, of £891.
The Earl of Bandon's demesne at Castlebernard in Co. Cork would appear to comprise an area of 527a. 1r. 3p. with a poor law valuation of £500 5s., including buildings.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands and Fisheries whether he can state if a scheme for the sub-division of the Devaney Farm in the townland of Leecarrow, parish of Kilmacshalgan, on the Cooper Estate, Co. Sligo, has been prepared by the Land Commission, and, if so, will he state the number of sub-divisions which the Land Commission propose to make of said farm.

A scheme for the division of the old holding of Dan Devaney, County Sligo, Record No. M, 190, situate on the Cooper Estate, County Sligo, in respect of the lands of Leccarrow comprising an area of 28a. 1r. 29p. has been prepared and is under consideration. Until the scheme has been dealt with by the Commissioners it is not possible to state into how many parcels the holding will be divided.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Road on O'Mahony Estate, Abbeyfeale.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands and Fisheries if he will state when the work of completing the construction of the road through the O'Mahony Estate, Mountcollins, Abbeyfeale, Co. Limerick, will be commenced and what is the cause of the delay; and if in view of the great inconvenience caused to the tenants owing to this road not being completed he will have the necessary work expedited.

Inquiry is still in progress regarding the road on the O'Mahony Estate at Mountcollins and I am not therefore at present in a position to add to my previous reply to the Deputy on this matter on the 28th May last.

I was down there about a fortnight ago and I am well aware of the serious inconvenience caused to the unfortunate tenants through the lack of this road. The people are unable to take away their hay or, for that matter, other crops. They are obliged to pay their rates and taxes, but they receive no return in the way of a road. As they said to me, “Where is the use in having land if we have not a way out?” This matter has been the subject of agitation for at least fifteen or sixteen years and I think it is time that the Parliamentary Secretary interested himself in having the roadway completed. The people have no way out. I think it is a disgraceful condition of things that there is no roadway built there.

This matter has been held over pending the division of another estate in the vicinity. In view of the fact that certain arrangements may be carried out later on, it might not be necessary to make this road.
There has been an agitation in this district for the last sixteen or eighteen years and the least the Government might do would be to convenience the people there.

MainHeading.RHead: Acquisition and Division of Kildare Lands
MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Acquisition and Division of Kildare Lands.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands and Fisheries if he will state what decision has been arrived at as a result of the inspection by the Land Commission respecting the acquisition and division of lands amongst the uneconomic holders and landless people in the townlands of Pluckerstown, Kilmoney, Feighcullen, Keelogues, Cannonstown, Bonaghmore, Boston, Cloncumber, Tullylost and Boherkill, in the Rathangan and Allen areas, Co. Kildare.

The Land Commission have had inquiry made into the occupancy of all the lands which the Deputy appears to have in mind as suitable for acquisition and have ascertained that all these lands have already been purchased under the Land Purchase Acts. It is not proposed at present to take any action for acquisition save in respect of the lands of Murphy minors, situate in Rathangan.
Is it the intention of the Land Commission to take over the lands of the Murphy minors?
Yes.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Kildare Bogs.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands and Fisheries if he will state what action the Land Commission intends to take on a resolution received from Kildare County Council, urging the absolute necessity of acquiring, draining and otherwise developing the bogs of the county in the interest of a large number of uneconomic holders, who are dependent on the sale of turf for a livelihood and are now nearly destitute.

The powers of the Land Commission to expend money on improvements are confined to expenditure on the improvement of lands purchased by them under the Land Purchase Acts. As lands in Co. Kildare which contain bogs are acquired by the Land Commission any improvements necessary will be carried out.
Will they be carried out immediately?
In due course.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Kildare Lands.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands and Fisheries (1) to state when the lands of Mellicent South and Barretstown, Co. Kildare, containing 150 acres, and at present let for grazing by the Land Commission, will be divided amongst the uneconomic holders and landless men of the district; (2) when the Land Commission intend to take possession of, and divide amongst the uneconomic holders of the district, the 434 acres of untenanted land in the townlands of Hughestown, Davidstown and Ballynacarrick Upper, in Co. Kildare, known as the Archbold Estate.

Schemes for the division of the lands of Millicent South and Barretstown, on the estate of Andrew Lyons, and the lands of Hughestown, Davidstown and Ballynacarrick Upper, on the Archbold estate, are in course of preparation and until these schemes have been completed and approved it will not be possible to state when the land will be divided. Arrangements for possession of the lands on the Archbold estate will be made when the scheme is ready to be put into operation.
Would it not be possible to have this land divided before the coming spring?
I could not answer that question at the moment. I know that schemes are under consideration.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Inniskea Islands Inhabitants.

Speaker.hpid: Mícheál O Cléirigh Mícheál O Cléirigh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands and Fisheries if he will state what arrangements have been made for the migration of the inhabitants of Inniskea Islands, North and South, to the mainland, and the names of the islanders who have accepted the terms offered by the Land Commission in connection with the migration scheme.

The Land Commission propose to utilise the lands of Surgeview or Nakil and Letterbeg, recently acquired from Mr. Patrick J. O'Reilly, in connection with the migration of the inhabitants of the Inniskea Islands. Over 400 acres are available and will be utilised for the provision of small holdings and grazing commonage.

Pending the completion and approval of a scheme for the division of the lands, conacre and grazing facilities are already available for the islanders, and work on the building of dwellinghouses is in progress, a provisional sanction of £2,000 for the first ten houses, as well as £500 for general improvements, having been made in February last to develop the lands.
I am not in a position to state the names of the islanders who will be migrated, as the scheme of division as yet is only in tentative form.
Have any of the islanders refused to accept the terms offered by the Land Commission?
Not that I know of.
They have not definitely accepted the terms?
They have, verbally.
